content: The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions for higher maximum penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002, also known as the Act, increases penalties for mail and wire fraud. It amends sections 1341 and 1343 of title 18, United States Code, by raising the maximum penalty from five to twenty years. Additionally, it introduces a new section 1348 for securities fraud, imposing fines or imprisonment up to 25 years for fraudulent schemes related to securities. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for mail and wire fraud, amending sections 1341 and 1343 of title 18, United States Code. It introduces a new section 1348 for securities fraud, with fines or imprisonment up to 25 years. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 introduces new penalties for securities fraud under section 1348 of title 18, United States Code, with fines or imprisonment up to 25 years. Additionally, amendments are made to section 1512 of title 18, United States Code, regarding tampering with records in official proceedings and the Federal Sentencing Guidelines. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 requests the United States Sentencing Commission to promptly review sentencing guidelines for securities fraud and related offenses, consider enhancements for corporate officers committing fraud, and submit policy recommendations to Congress. The Sentencing Commission is asked to ensure that guidelines reflect the seriousness of securities and pension fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 requests the United States Sentencing Commission to review sentencing guidelines for securities fraud and related offenses, ensuring they reflect the seriousness of such fraud. The guidelines should also consider enhancements for corporate officers committing fraud and make necessary changes to ensure adequacy in cases of obstruction of justice and fraud offenses with a significant number of victims. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to review and update sentencing guidelines for securities fraud and related offenses, ensuring they align with the seriousness of the crimes. The guidelines should also address enhancements for corporate officers involved in fraud and make necessary changes to ensure adequacy in cases of obstruction of justice and fraud offenses with numerous victims. The Commission is urged to act promptly and finalize the guidelines or amendments within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include claims for violations of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of securities as non-dischargeable debts. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, makes claims for violations of securities laws or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of securities non-dischargeable debts. This includes any court orders, settlement agreements, or decrees for payments owed by the debtor. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section requiring corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. Failure to comply with this certification can result in criminal penalties of fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years. The new section in Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, requires corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. Failure to comply can result in criminal penalties of fines exceeding $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years. SEC. 7 introduces penalties for attempts and conspiracies to commit offenses against the United States. SEC. 8 increases criminal penalties under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, raising fines to $5,000,000 and imprisonment to 20 years. SEC. 9 introduces temporary freeze authority for the Securities and Exchange Commission. SEC. 9 introduces temporary freeze authority for the Securities and Exchange Commission, allowing the Commission to petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow extraordinary payments for 45 days during an investigation involving possible violations of the Federal securities laws. The Securities and Exchange Commission can obtain a temporary order to freeze extraordinary payments in an interest-bearing account for 45 days. The order becomes effective immediately, is served to the parties involved, and remains enforceable unless modified by a court within 45 days. The court can extend the effective period of a temporary order for up to 45 additional days, not exceeding a total of 90 days. If violations are charged before the order expires, it remains in effect until legal proceedings conclude, with the option to petition the court for review. The court can extend a temporary order for up to 45 additional days, not exceeding 90 days. If no violations are charged before the order expires, the escrow will terminate, and disputed payments will be returned. A technical amendment is made to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 10. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 empower the Commission to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. This authority allows the Commission to issue orders prohibiting such individuals from holding these positions permanently or for a specified period. The Commission has the authority to issue orders prohibiting individuals who have violated regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers, either permanently or for a specified period. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize actions harmful to individuals providing truthful information to law enforcement regarding Federal offenses. Penalties include fines or imprisonment up to 10 years.
